ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: interesting examination of holocaust testimony from several angles, most interesting recurrent discussion was that of truth (objective facts) vs truthfulness (more ambiguous meaning)

You learn how to reconcile with one of humanity's greatest atrocities by seeking nuance rather than simplistic narratives. You also engage with many perspectives--including that of perpetrators and even "fake" victims. For a crime that is so horrible, this class tries to understand it without imposing a grand framework. That's what makes this worthwhile.

I came away with a skillset through which to understand the process of historicization and the role of testimony in creating a historical archive. I also have a much more nuanced understanding of the Holocaust, which has quite frankly transformed the way that I not only understand Jewish history but also the world.

I learned about the distinct periods of thought/modes of analysis in the history of holocaust studies. I was challenged to think critically about topics I had not been previously exposed tothe sacralization of survivors, the role of testimony in research, the notion of the Holocaust as paradigmatic of genocide.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
strengths: our class had really great discussions and got along really well
weaknesses: the exact same discussion format each week got a little repetitive/boring, i feel like we could have found more creative ways to engage with the material and connect the weeks more

Strengths: Professor Dean is just excellent. She is an excellent discussion leader and has a gift for remembering each student's contributions (it's actually incredible how she can remember a comment you made even weeks ago). She also will make a concerted effort to meet with you for office hours. She's brilliant. I was also lucky to have a fantastic group of classmates in the seminar. It's clear everyone is engaged and is prepared to engage in the class. 

Weaknesses: The class is excellent, but there's one change I would consider for the syllabus: I wish we could have started with the historical context of European genocides, instead of ending with it. That historical context would've likely shaped a lot of future conversations.

The readings and discussions were definitely the biggest strength of this course. I thoroughly enjoyed each reading, and while the reading load was quite heavy, it all came together very nicely. I wish that we had more assignments throughout the course, however. The only assignments were 2 papers and a brief set of discussion questions, which were all very enriching but did not facilitate consistent feedback.

Strengths: the diversity of course readings, the length of class blocks, the freedom to chose the focus of papers

Weaknesses: n/a

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, it is an interesting evaluation of the way we study the holocaust that includes a variety of perspectives
Yes! I recommend this seminar with the strongest enthusiasm.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. I came away with a much more refined understanding of the Holocaust and its implications.
Absolutely. If you are interested in the Holocaust, this is a great course that prompts students to think critically and ask interesting questions.
